[[File:Michelangelo - Dream of Life NG8.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|''The Dream of Life'', by unknown [[Mannerism|Mannerist]] painter, ca. 1533]] The '''dream argument''' is the postulation that the act of dreaming provides preliminary evidence that the [[sense]]s we trust to distinguish [[reality]] from [[illusion]] should not be fully trusted, and therefore, any state that is dependent on our senses should at the very least be carefully examined and rigorously tested to determine whether it is in fact reality. == Synopsis == {{Descartes}} While one [[dream]]s, one does not normally [[lucid dreaming|realize]] one is dreaming. This has led [[philosophy|philosophers]] to wonder whether it is possible for one ever to be [[certainty|certain]], at any given point in time, that one is not in fact dreaming, or whether indeed it could be possible for one to remain in a perpetual dream state and never experience the reality of [[wakefulness]] at all.{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}} In the [[Western philosophy|West]], this philosophical puzzle was referred to by [[Plato]] ([[Theaetetus (dialogue)|''Theaetetus'']] 158b-d) and [[Aristotle]] ([[Metaphysics (Aristotle)|''Metaphysics'']] 1011a6). Having received serious attention in [[René Descartes]]' ''[[Meditations on First Philosophy]]'', the dream [[Logical argument|argument]] has become one of the most prominent [[skeptical hypothesis|skeptical hypotheses]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2016}} This type of argument is sometimes referred to as the "[[Zhuangzi dreamed he was a butterfly|Zhuangzi paradox]]":
He who dreams of drinking wine may weep when morning comes; he who dreams of weeping may in the morning go off to hunt. While he is dreaming he does not know it is a dream, and in his dream he may even try to interpret a dream. Only after he wakes does he know it was a dream. And someday there will be a great awakening when we know that this is all a great dream. Yet the stupid believe they are awake, busily and brightly assuming they understand things, calling this man ruler, that one herdsman—how dense! Confucius and you are both dreaming! And when I say you are dreaming, I am dreaming, too. Words like these will be labeled the Supreme Swindle. Yet, after ten thousand generations, a great sage may appear who will know their meaning, and it will still be as though he appeared with astonishing speed.莊子, 齊物論, 12. ''Zhuàngzi'', "Discussion on making all things equal," 12. ''from'' Zhuàngzi, Burton Watson trans., ''Chuang Tzu'' (New York: Columbia University Press, 1996), 43. {{ISBN|978-0-231-10595-8}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=f1BvUUUVRLEC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA43#v=onepage&q&f=false]
One of the first philosophers to posit the dream argument formally was the [[Yogachara]] philosopher [[Vasubandhu]] (4th to 5th century C.E.) in his "[[Twenty verses on appearance only]]." The dream argument came to feature prominently in [[Mahayana]] and [[Tibetan Buddhist]] philosophy. Some [[reality in Buddhism|schools of thought ]] (''e.g.'', [[Dzogchen]]) consider ''perceived [[reality]]'' to be literally unreal. As [[Chögyal Namkhai Norbu]] puts it: "In a real sense, all the visions that we see in our lifetime are like a big dream . . . ."[[Chögyal Namkhai Norbu]] ''Dream Yoga And The Practice Of Natural Light'' Edited and introduced by Michael Katz, Snow Lion Publications, Ithaca, NY, {{ISBN|1-55939-007-7}}, pp. 42, 46, 48, 96, 105. In this context, the term 'visions' denotes not only [[visual perception]]s, but also appearances perceived through all [[sense]]s, including [[hearing|sounds]], [[Odour|smell]]s, [[taste]]s, and [[touch|tactile sensations]], and [[mental operations|operations]] on perceived mental objects. == Hutton's paradox == A paradox concerning dreams and the nature of reality was described by the British writer Eric Bond Hutton in 1989."Adversaria V," ''Write Justified'', Spring 1989. For Hutton's definitive statement on the subject see "Hutton's Paradox," ''Fortean Times'', April 2015, archived online [https://archive.org/stream/Fortean_Times_April_2015_UK#page/n71/mode/2up here]. As a child Hutton often had [[lucid dream|lucid dreams]], in which everything seemed as real as in waking life. This led him to wonder whether life itself was a dream, even whether he existed only in somebody else's dream. Sometimes he had [[pre-lucid dream|pre-lucid dreams]], in which more often than not he concluded he was awake. Such dreams disturbed him greatly, but one day he came up with a magic formula for use in them: "If I find myself asking 'Am I dreaming?' it proves I am, for the question would never occur to me in waking life." Yet, such is the nature of dreams, he could never recall it when he needed to. Many years later, when he wrote a piece about solipsism and his childhood interest in dreams, he was struck by a contradiction in his earlier reasoning. True, asking oneself "Am I dreaming?" ''in a dream'' would seem to prove one is. Yet that is precisely what he had often asked himself in waking life. Therein lay a paradox. What was he to conclude? That it does not prove one is dreaming? Or that life really is a dream? == Simulated reality == {{See also|Simulated reality|Simulation hypothesis}} Dreaming provides a springboard for those who question whether our own reality may be an illusion. The ability of the mind to be tricked into believing a mentally generated world is the "real world" means at least one variety of simulated reality is a common, even nightly event.[https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=bttg3B5CZOIC&oi=fnd&pg=PA96&dq=dreaming+simulated+reality&ots=iPQG-evOVr&sig=_7NT_42ES4XXK8iXz02Necg5W9c#PPA103,M1 ''Joseph Barbera, Henry Moller'', Dreaming, Virtual Reality, and Presence]. Those who argue that the world is not simulated must concede that the mind—at least the sleeping mind—is not itself an entirely reliable mechanism for attempting to differentiate reality from illusion.[http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WD0-45MGTWX-N&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=23fdaaef820b1ccd4be0982568286789 ''Giuliana A. L. Mazzoni and Elizabeth F. Loftus'', When Dreams Become Reality]. {{cquote| Whatever I have accepted until now as most true has come to me through my senses. But occasionally I have found that they have deceived me, and it is unwise to trust completely those who have deceived us even once.|||René DescartesRené Descartes, [http://www.earlymoderntexts.com/pdfbits/dm1.pdf Meditations on First Philosophy].}} == Critical discussion == In the past, philosophers [[John Locke]] and [[Thomas Hobbes]] have separately attempted to refute Descartes's account of the dream argument. Locke claimed that you cannot experience pain in dreams. Various scientific studies conducted within the last few decades provided evidence against Locke's claim by concluding that pain in dreams can occur but the pain isn't as severe{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}. Philosopher Ben Springett has said that Locke might respond to this by stating that the agonising pain of stepping in to a fire is non-comparable to stepping in to a fire in a dream. Hobbes claimed that dreams are susceptible to absurdity while the waking life is not.{{cite web|url=http://www.iep.utm.edu/dreaming/#SH1b|title=Dreaming, Philosophy of – Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy|work=utm.edu}} Many contemporary philosophers have attempted to refute dream skepticism in detail (see, e.g., Stone (1984)).{{cite journal|author=Stone, Jim|year=1984|title=Dreaming and Certainty|journal=Philosophical Studies|volume=45|issue=3|pages=353–368|doi=10.1007/BF00355443|url=http://philpapers.org/archive/STODAC.pdf}} [[Ernest Sosa]] (2007) devoted a chapter of a monograph to the topic, in which he presented a new theory of dreaming and argued that his theory raises a new argument for skepticism, which he attempted to refute. In ''A Virtue Epistemology: Apt Belief and Reflective Knowledge'', he states: "in dreaming we do not really believe; we only make-believe."Sosa, Ernest (2007). A Virtue Epistemology: Apt Belief and Reflective Knowledge. New York: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-19-929702-3}}. Jonathan Ichikawa (2008) and Nathan Ballantyne & Ian Evans (2010) have offered critiques of Sosa's proposed solution. Ichikawa argued that as we cannot tell whether our beliefs in waking life are truly beliefs and not imaginings, like in a dream, we are still not able to tell whether we are awake or dreaming. [[Norman Malcolm]] in his monograph "Dreaming" (published in 1959) elaborated on Wittgenstein's question as to whether it really mattered if people who tell dreams "really had these images while they slept, or whether it merely seems so to them on waking". He argues that the sentence "I am asleep" is a senseless form of words; that dreams cannot exist independently of the waking impression; and that scepticism based on dreaming "comes from confusing the historical and dream telling senses...[of]...the past tense". (page 120). In the chapter: "Do I Know I Am Awake ?" he argues that we do not have to say: "I know that I am awake" simply because it would be absurd to deny that one is awake. The dream hypothesis is also used to develop other philosophical concepts, such as Valberg's [[personal horizon]]: what this world would be internal to if ''this'' were all a dream.{{cite book|last=Valberg|first=J.J.|title=Dream, Death, and the Self|year=2007|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=9780691128597|url=http://press.princeton.edu/titles/8416.html}} == See also == * [[Cartesian doubt]] * [[Consensus reality]] * [[Evil demon]] * [[False awakening]] * [[Maya (illusion)]] * [[Multiverse]] * [[Reality in Buddhism]] * [[Social simulation]] * [[Solipsism]] == Notes == {{reflist|30em}} == References == * {{cite journal |first=Nathan |last=Ballantyne |first2=Ian |last2=Evans |title=Sosa's Dream |journal=Philosophical Studies |volume=148 |issue=2 |year=2010 |pages=249–252 |url=http://www.u.arizona.edu/~wnb/Ballantyne-Evans_SosasDream.pdf |doi=10.1007/s11098-008-9309-y }} * {{cite journal |last=Ichikawa |first=Jonathan |title=Skepticism and the Imagination Model of Dreaming |journal=The Philosophical Quarterly |year=2008 |volume=58 |issue=232 |pages=519–527 |doi=10.1111/j.1467-9213.2007.546.x }} * {{cite book |authorlink=Ernest Sosa |first=Ernest |last=Sosa |title=A Virtue Epistemology: Apt Belief and Reflective Knowledge |location=New York |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=2007 |isbn=978-0-19-929702-3 }} * {{cite journal |first=Jim |last=Stone |title=Dreaming and Certainty |journal=Philosophical Studies |volume=45 |issue=3 |year=1984 |pages=353–368 |doi=10.1007/BF00355443 }} Malcolm, N. (1959) Dreaming London: Routledge & Kegan Paul, 2nd Impression 1962. {{Paradoxes}} {{Skepticism}} [[Category:Epistemology]] [[Category:Arguments in philosophy of mind]] [[Category:Internalism and externalism]] [[Category:Reality]] [[Category:Skepticism]] [[Category:Science fiction themes]] [[Category:Philosophical paradoxes]]

{{histphil}} '''Early modern philosophy''' (also '''classical modern philosophy''')<ref>Jeffrey Tlumak, ''Classical Modern Philosophy: A Contemporary Introduction'', Routledge, 2006, p. xi: "[''Classical Modern Philosophy''] is a guide through the systems of the seven brilliant seventeenth- and eighteenth-century European philosophers most regularly taught in college Modern Philosophy courses".</ref><ref name="Schacht">[[Richard Schacht]], ''Classical Modern Philosophers: Descartes to Kant'', Routledge, 2013, p. 1: "Seven men have come to stand out from all of their counterparts in what has come to be known as the 'modern' period in the history of philosophy (i.e., the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries): Descartes, Spinoza, Leibniz, Locke, Berkeley, Hume and Kant".</ref> is a period in the [[history of philosophy]] at the beginning or overlapping with the period known as [[modern philosophy]].
==Overview== The [[early modern period]] in history is roughly 1500–1789,<ref>[[Marshall Berman]]. 1982. ''[[All That Is Solid Melts into Air]]: The Experience of Modernity''. New York: Simon and Schuster. {{ISBN|0-671-24602-X}}. London: Verso. pp. 16–17. {{ISBN|0-86091-785-1}}. Paperback reprint New York: Viking Penguin, 1988. {{ISBN|0-14-010962-5}}.</ref> but the label "early modern philosophy" is usually used to refer to a more specific period of time.
In the narrowest sense, the term is used to refer principally to the [[17th-century philosophy|philosophy of the 17th century]], posited to have begun with [[René Descartes]]; to have included [[Thomas Hobbes]], [[Blaise Pascal]], [[Baruch Spinoza]]; and to have ended with [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz]] and [[Isaac Newton]]. Many stretch this period to [[18th-century philosophy]] (the [[Age of Enlightenment]]), thus including [[John Locke]], [[George Berkeley]], and [[David Hume]].<ref name="Schacht"/>
The term is sometimes used more broadly and early modern philosophy is considered to have begun in the 16th century<ref>[[Brian Leiter]] (ed.), ''The Future for Philosophy'', Oxford University Press, 2006, p. 44 n. 2.</ref> with [[Niccolò Machiavelli]], [[Martin Luther]] and [[John Calvin]]; to have also included [[Michel Eyquem de Montaigne]], [[Francis Bacon]], [[Giambattista Vico]], [[Voltaire]] and [[Thomas Paine]]; and to have ended at the latest in 1804 with the death of [[Immanuel Kant]]. Considered in this way, the period spans from [[Renaissance philosophy]] to the [[Age of Enlightenment]].

{{Infobox book | name = Esoteric Buddhism | image = Esotericbudd.jpg | image_size = 220px | caption = 5th edition, 1885 | author = [[Alfred Percy Sinnett|A. P. Sinnett]] | country = [[United Kingdom]] | language = English | subject = [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|Theosophy]] | genre = | publisher = Trübner & Co | pub_date = 1883 (1st edition) | pages = XX–215 | oclc = 458880554 | external_url = http://blavatskyarchives.com/theosophypdfs/sinnett_esoteric_buddhism_first_edition_1883.pdf }} {{Italic title}} '''''Esoteric Buddhism''''' is a book originally published in 1883 in London; it was compiled by a member of the [[Theosophical Society]], [[Alfred Percy Sinnett|A. P. Sinnett]].{{sfn|Formats and editions}}{{sfn|Kuhn|1992|p=154}} It was one of the first books written for the purpose explain of the [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|theosophy]] for the wide range of readers,{{sfn|Lavoie|2012|p=197}} and was "made up of the [[Mahatma Letters|author's correspondence]] with an [[Koot Hoomi|Indian mystic]]."{{sfn|WorldCat Identities}} This is the most significant theosophical work of the author. According to [[Nicholas Goodrick-Clarke|Goodrick-Clarke]], it "disseminated the basic teachings of Theosophy in its new Asian cast."{{sfn|Goodrick-Clarke|2004|p=12}}{{refn|group=note|"His [Sinnett's] second book, ''Esoteric Buddhism,'' an outline of some of the main teachings of theosophy, attracted much attention and served as a harbinger of [[Helena Blavatsky|H.P.B.'s]] monumental work, ''[[The Secret Doctrine]]''."{{sfn|Ryan|1975|loc=Ch. 9}}}} == From history of compilation == Through the mediation of [[Helena Blavatsky|Blavatsky]]{{refn|group=note|P. Washington wrote that Blavatsky with Sinnett and his wife Patience has been in sincere friendship.{{sfn|Washington|1995|loc=Ch. 3}}}} Sinnett began a correspondence in 1880 with the two adepts, who sponsored the Theosophical Society, the [[mahatma]]s [[Kuthumi]] and [[Morya (Theosophy)|Morya]].{{sfn|Theosopedia}}{{refn|group=note|Goodrick-Clarke wrote that "the very concept of the [[mahatma|Masters]]" is the [[Rosicrucianism|Rosicrucian]] idea of "invisible and secret adepts, working for the advancement of humanity."{{sfn|Goodrick-Clarke|2004|p=6}} And Tillett stated: "The concept of Masters or Mahatmas as presented by [[Helena Blavatsky|HPB]] involved a mixture of western and eastern ideas; she located most of them in India or Tibet. Both she and Colonel [[Henry Steel Olcott|Olcott]] claimed to have seen and to be in communication with Masters. In Western [[occultism]] the idea of 'Supermen' has been found in such schools as... the fraternities established by [[Martinez de Pasqually|de Pasqually]] and [[Louis Claude de Saint-Martin|de Saint-Martin]]."{{sfn|Tillett|1986|p=966}}}} [[Olav Hammer|Hammer]] noted that between 1880 and 1884 Sinnett received from the mahatmas circa one hundred twenty letters with explanation of "[[occult]] cosmology". From this material, he attempted to formulate in his new book "the basis of a revised theosophy."{{sfn|Hammer|2003|p=381}} By foundation of the book became "Cosmological notes" received from the Mahatma Morya{{sfn|Barker|1924|loc=Letters 12, 13}} together with a long series of answers to questions sent by mahatma Kuthumi{{sfn|Barker|1924|loc=Letters 14–18}} during the summer of 1882.{{sfn|Hanson|1980|loc=Ch. IX}}
[[Tallapragada Subba Row|Subba Row]] received from his Master mahatma Morya the instruction to provide assistance to Sinnett in his work on the book, but, according to the memoirs of the author, he did it reluctantly, and what little help. The main help came from the mahatmas through Blavatsky in the form of answers to the questions referred to her by the author.{{sfn|Sinnett|1986|p=23}} == Contents of the book ==
#[[Esoteric]] Teachers. #The Constitution of Man. #The Planetary Chain. #The World Periods. #[[Sukhavati|Devachan]]. #[[Astral plane|Kama Loca]]. #The Human Tide-Wave. #The Progress of Humanity. #[[Gautama Buddha|Buddha]]. #[[Nirvana]]. #The Universe. #The Doctrine Reviewed.{{Sfn|Sinnett|1885}}{{sfn|WorldCat}}
In preface to the original edition author says that [[exoteric]] [[Buddhism]] "has remained in closer union with the [[esoteric]] doctrine" than any other [[Major religious groups|world religion]]. Thus, specification of the "inner knowledge" addressed to modern readers will be connected with the familiar features of the Buddhist teaching. Sinnett argues that esoteric teaching "be most conveniently studied in its Buddhist aspect."{{Sfn|Sinnett|1885|p=xviii}}{{sfn|Hammer|2003|p=123}} === Esoteric teachers === At the beginning of the first chapter the author makes the following statement:
"I am bringing to my readers knowledge which I have obtained by favour{{refn|group=note|[[Mahatma Letters|Letters from mahatmas]] formed the basis of two theosophical books by Sinnett.{{sfn|Hammer|2003|p=61}}}} rather than by effort. It will not be found the less valuable on that account; I venture, on the contrary, to declare that it will be found of incalculably greater value, easily as I have obtained it, than any results in a similar direction which I could possibly have procured by ordinary methods of research."{{Sfnm|Sinnett|1885|1p=1|Лесевич|1887|2p=16}}
On the question of the whereabouts of his teachers Sinnett says that for a long time in [[Tibet]] there is a "certain secret region," hitherto unknown and inaccessible to ordinary people and for those living in the surrounding mountains as well as for visitors, "in which adepts have always congregated. But the country generally was not in Buddha's time, as it has since become, the chosen habitation of the great brotherhood. Much more than they are at present, were the Mahatmas in former times, distributed about the world." But the development of civilization has led to the fact that many occultists gathered in Tibet. The system of rules and laws for them has been developed in the 14th century by [[Je Tsongkhapa|Tsong-ka-pa]].{{sfn|Sinnett|1885|pp=181–182}}{{sfn|Lopez|1999|p=50}} === The constitution of man === The author argues that "a complete, or perfect man" is made up of [[Septenary (Theosophy)|seven elements]]:
#The [[Physical body|Physical Body]] (''[[Rūpa]]''). #Vitality (''[[Prana]]'', or ''Jiva''). #[[Subtle body|Astral Body]] (''Linga Sharira''). #Animal [[Soul]] ([[Kāma|''Kāma Rūpa'']]). #Human Soul ([[Manas (early Buddhism)|''Manas'']]). #Spiritual Soul (''[[Buddhi]]''). #[[Spirit]] ([[Ātman (Buddhism)|''Ātma'']]).{{Sfnm|Sinnett|1885|1p=24|Goodrick-Clarke|2004|2p=17}}
=== The world periods === A French philosopher [[René Guénon]] stated that the central place of the Theosophical doctrine [which there is in Sinnett's book] is occupied the "idea of evolution." He then wrote that, according to the Theosophical teaching, there are
"seven '[[Root race|mother-races]]' succeed one another in the course of a 'world period', that is to say while the 'wave of life' sojourns on a given planet. Each 'race' includes seven 'sub-races', each of which is divided into seven 'branches'. On the other hand, the 'wave of life' successively runs through seven globes in a '[[Round (Theosophy)|round]]', and this 'round' is repeated seven times in a same 'planetary chain', after which the 'wave of life' passes to another 'chain', composed likewise of seven planets which will be traversed seven times in their turn. Thus there are seven 'chains' in a 'planetary system', also called an 'enterprise of evolution'; and finally, our solar system is formed of ten 'planetary systems'... We are presently in the fifth 'race' of our 'world period', and in the fourth 'round' of the 'chain' of which the earth forms part and in which it occupies the fourth rank. This 'chain' is also the fourth of our 'planetary system'."{{sfnm|Sinnett|1885|1pp=55, 131|Guénon|2004|2p=98}}
=== Man after death === In the fifth chapter of his book, Sinnett explains the fate of man after death. Of the seven components that make up our personality, the three lower at the time of physical death, moving away from us.{{Sfn|Sinnett|1885|p=77}}{{sfn|Hammer|2003|p=466}} The four upper components move on [[Astral plane|Kama loca]], and "from there [soul] proceed to Devachan, a kind of theosophical version of heaven." (The analogy should not be carried overly; Sinnett argues that Devachan is a state, not a place.{{Sfn|Sinnett|1885|p=81}}{{sfn|Hammer|2003|p=466}}) Then these four components divide themselves, the law of [[karma]] specifies that it will happen to them—different souls receive different devachanic experience. Only after a long stay in this state, the soul [[Rebirth (Buddhism)|reincarnates]].{{refn|group=note|"The lower four, or quaternary, are transitory, while the upper triad is related to the eternal element in man, his real nature and identity with the universal soul."{{Sfn|Sinnett|1885|p=24}}{{sfn|Goodrick-Clarke|2004|p=17}}}} New incarnations on the [[Physical plane|earth plane]] are actually rather rare, "but re-birth in less than fifteen hundred years is spoken of as almost impossible."{{Sfn|Sinnett|1885|p=98}}{{sfn|Hammer|2003|p=466}} Sinnett says that the mediums contact with the inhabitants of Devachan, but very rare, and in this time occurs the following:
"The spirit of the [[Psychic|sensitive]], getting odylized,{{sfn|Melton|2001}} so to say, by the [[Aura (paranormal)|aura]] of the spirit in the Devachan, ''becomes'' for a few minutes that departed personality, and writes in the handwriting of the latter, in his language and in his thoughts, as they were during his lifetime. The two spirits become blended in one, and the preponderance of one over the other during such phenomena determines the preponderance of personality in the characteristic exhibited. Thus it may incidentally be observed, what is called ''[[rapport]],'' is, in plain fact, an identity of molecular vibration between the astral part of the incarnate medium and the astral part of the disincarnate personality."{{Sfnm|Sinnett|1885|1p=95|Hammer|2003|2p=467}}
=== Occult philosophy === [[File:Man on planet.jpg|thumb|left|220px|
Diagram "Man on a Planet".{{refn|group=note|"Man evolves in seven major or root-races; 49 minor races; and the subordinate races or offshoots. The arrow indicates the direction taken by the evolutionary impulse.
I, II, III, IV, etc., are the seven major or [[root race|root-races]].
1, 2, 3, etc., are the minor races.
a, a, a, are the subordinate or offshoot races.
N, the initial and terminal point of evolution on the planet.
S, the axial point where the development equilibrates or adjusts itself in each race evolution.
E, the equatorial points wherein the descending arc intellect overcomes spirituality and in the ascending arc spirituality outstrips intellect.
A word or two [globe, earth] added to make it apply as well to a whole manwantaric chain of worlds."{{sfn|Barker|1924|loc=Letter 14}}}}
]] Lavoie noted that in Sinnett's book there are the two major questions – "the structure of the universe and [[spiritual evolution]]." He selected "some key terms" in the book.{{sfn|Lavoie|2012|p=197}} [[Avīci|'''Avitchi''']] is a state "of punishment reached only in exceptional cases and by exceptional natures." The usual man will work his karma out in a new [[Rebirth (Buddhism)|incarnation]].{{sfn|Sinnett|1885|p=93}}{{sfn|Lavoie|2012|p=197}}
[[Sukhavati|'''Devachan''']] is a state of greatest bliss where "the levels of intensity and the duration of stay are based on the karma one produces in his/her lifetime."{{sfn|Sinnett|1885|p=92}}{{sfn|Lavoie|2012|p=197}}
'''Eighth sphere''' is a planet associated with our planetary chain that is more materialistic than the earth.{{sfn|Sinnett|1885|p=113}}{{sfn|Lavoie|2012|p=197}} The Soul in the mean of the fifth round "can be sent to the eighth sphere for annihilation if it has developed a positive attraction to materialism and a repulsion of spirituality."{{sfn|Sinnett|1885|p=162}}{{sfn|Lavoie|2012|p=197}}
[[Astral plane|'''Kama loca''']] is "an unconscious state of gestation. It is here that the fourth principle (the animal soul) is separated from the others." The fourth component and some of the fifth component stays in Kama loca while "the rest of the principles continue on in their spiritual evolution."{{sfn|Sinnett|1885|pp=100–101}}{{sfn|Lavoie|2012|p=198}} The Ego's duration in Kama loca can last from few moments to years.{{sfn|Sinnett|1885|p=97}}{{sfn|Lavoie|2012|p=198}}
'''[[Manvantara]]''' is a period of activity or manifestation.{{sfn|Glossary|1999}} There are three different manvantaras: 1) the mahamanvantara, 2) the solar manvantara, 3) the minor manvantara.{{sfn|Sinnett|1885|pp=196–197}}{{sfn|Lavoie|2012|p=198}}
[[Monad (philosophy)|'''Monad''']] is upper triad of the seven principles of man (Atma-Buddhi-Manas).{{sfn|Glossary|1999}}{{sfn|Lavoie|2012|p=198}}
'''[[Pralaya]]''' is a state of nonbeing.{{sfn|Glossary|1999}} "Pralaya is described by Sinnett as a type of sleep, rest, or a time of inactivity." There are three different pralayas: 1) the mahapralaya, 2) the solar pralaya, 3) the minor pralaya.{{sfn|Sinnett|1885|pp=196–197}}{{sfn|Lavoie|2012|p=198}}
[[Round (Theosophy)|'''Round''']] is a full turnover via the seven globes. "During each round there is a maximum of 120 incarnations for each monad in each race with the average of 8,000 years between incarnations."{{sfn|Sinnett|1885|p=143}}{{sfn|Lavoie|2012|p=198}} Man begins as a monad and dwells in seven major races on each of the seven planets. Each race takes circa one million years. Only 12,000 of those will be used for objective existence on the planets. The rest of that time will be used mainly in a subjective existence on the [[Mental plane|devachanic plane]]. "This meant that out of one million years – 988,000 years are spent reaping the effects of karma."{{sfn|Sinnett|1885|pp=142–143}}{{sfn|Lavoie|2012|p=199}}{{refn|group=note|In ''Mahatma Letters'' (letter 14) this number is "slightly different."{{sfn|Lavoie|2012|p=244}} The letter states that man "has passed in all his lives upon our planet (in this Round) but 77,700 years he has been in the subjective spheres 922,300 years."{{sfn|Barker|1924|loc=Letter 14}}}} A branch race is one of seven belonging to a subrace, itself one of seven belonging to a main race. "If each monad in each race incarnates once, the total number of incarnations in each globe would be 343 (7 branch races x 7 subraces x 7 [[root race]]s); however, each monad incarnates typically at a minimum of two times and some even more frequently."{{sfn|Sinnett|1885|pp=60–61, 140}}{{sfn|Lavoie|2012|p=199}} In ''Mahatma Letters'' it is said that "one life in each of the seven root-races; seven lives in each of the 49 sub-races – or 7 x 7 x 7 = 343 and add 7 more. And then a series of lives in offshoot and branchlet races; making the total incarnations of man in each station or planet 777."{{sfn|Barker|1924|loc=Letter 14}}{{sfn|Lavoie|2012|p=244}} === Theosophical Buddha === The ninth chapter of Sinnett's book called "Buddha". It begins with the words:
"The historical Buddha, as known to the custodians of the esoteric doctrine, is a personage whose birth is not invested with the quaint marvels popular story has crowded round it. Nor was his progress to adeptship traced by the literal occurrence of the supernatural struggles depicted in symbolic legend. On the other hand, the incarnation, which may outwardly be described as the birth of Buddha, is certainly not regarded by occult science as an event like any other birth, nor the spiritual development through which Buddha passed during his earth-life a mere process of intellectual evolution, like the mental history of any other philosopher. The mistake which ordinary European writers make in dealing with a problem of this sort lies in their inclination to treat exoteric legend either as a record of a miracle about which no more need be said, or as pure myth, putting merely a fantastic decoration on a remarkable life."{{Sfnm|Sinnett|1885|1p=167|Lopez|2008|2pр=187–188}}
According to [[Donald S. Lopez Jr.|Lopez]], author of ''Esoteric Buddhism'' "has a broader view of the Buddha" than that of Western Buddhologists and scholars of Oriental studies. Sinnett stated that the Buddha is simply one of a row "of adepts who have appeared over the course of the centuries."{{Sfn|Lopez|2008|p=189}} Buddha's next incarnation happened approximately sixty years after his death. He appeared as [[Adi Shankara|Shankara]], the well-known Vedantic philosopher. Sinnett noted that for the uninitiated it is known that date of Shankara's birth is one thousand years after Buddha's death, and that he was hostile to Buddhism. Sinnett wrote that the Buddha came as Shankara "to fill up some gaps and repair certain errors in his own previous teaching."{{Sfn|Sinnett|1885|p=176}} The Buddha had leaved "from the practice of earlier adepts by opening the path" to adeptship to men of all [[caste]]s. "Although well-intentioned, this led" to a deterioration of occult knowledge when it was penetrated into ignominious hands.{{Sfn|Lopez|2008|p=189}} Sinnett wrote that to further appeared a need "to take no candidates except from the class which, on the whole, by reason of its hereditary advantages, is likely to be the best nursery of fit candidates."{{Sfn|Sinnett|1885|p=177}}
Sinnett claimed that the Buddha's next incarnation was as the great Tibetan adept reformer of the 14th century Tsong-ka-pa.{{Sfn|Sinnett|1885|p=181}} === Against blind faith === In the tenth chapter Sinnett expresses (as well as the Mahatmas) his very negative attitude to religiosity of any kind. He argues:
"Nothing can produce more disastrous effects on human progress, as regards the destiny of individuals, than the very prevalent notion that one religion followed out in a pious spirit, is as good as another, and that if such and such doctrines are perhaps absurd when you look into them, the great majority of good people will never think of their absurdity, but will recite them in a blamelessly devoted attitude of mind."{{Sfnm|Sinnett|1885|1pp=194–195|Guénon|2004|2p=126}}{{refn|group=note|"It is priestly imposture that rendered these gods so terrible to man; it is religion that makes of him the selfish bigot, the fanatic that hates all mankind out of his own sect without rendering him any better or more moral for it. It is the belief in God and gods that makes two-thirds of humanity the slaves of a handful of those who deceive them under the false pretence of saving them. <...> In our [Tibetan] temples there is neither a god nor gods worshipped, only the thrice sacred memory of the greatest as the holiest [[Gautama Buddha|''man'']] that ever lived."{{sfn|Barker|1924|loc=Letter 10}}}}
== Criticism == The presence of a secret or esoteric teaching in Buddhism is "not accepted by orthodox Buddhist."{{sfn|Harris}} For example, [[Thomas Rhys Davids|Rhys Davids]] wrote:
"In this connection, I shall doubtless be expected to say a few words on Theosophy, if only because one of the books giving an account of that very curious and widely spread movement has been called ''Esoteric Buddhism.'' It has always been a point of wonder to me why the author should have chosen this particular title for his treatise. For if there is anything that can be said with absolute certainty about the book it is, that it is not esoteric, and not Buddhism. The original Buddhism was the very contrary of esoteric."{{sfn|Rhys Davids|1896|pp=209–210}}{{refn|group=note|Nonetheless [[Christmas Humphreys|Humphreys]] wrote that "Buddha's Teaching was not born from a spiritual vacuum, but was an expression of some portion of that Gupta Vidya 'the accumulated Wisdom of the ages', which antedates all known religions."{{sfn|Humphreys|2012|p=23}}
"'''Gupta-vidya''' (Sanskrit) ''Gupta-vidyā'' [from ''gupta'' from the verbal root ''gup'' to conceal, preserve + ''vidyā'' knowledge, wisdom] Secret knowledge, secret wisdom; the source of all religions and philosophies known to the world: theosophy, the ancient wisdom-religion, the esoteric philosophy."{{sfn|Glossary|1999}}}}{{refn|group=note|Sinnett received instructions from the Tibetan Masters, and Rhys Davids believed that [[Lamaism]] was a Religion not only different from Buddhism, but and being in his time in antagonism with the teachings and the institutions of original Buddhism.{{sfn|Лесевич|1887|p=16}} See also a book by Eva M. Dargyay{{sfn|Dargyay|1979}}}}
[[René Guénon|Guénon's]] opinion on the subject was the same. He wrote that never was genuine "esoteric Buddhism." The ancient Buddhism was substantially an exoteric teaching "serving as theoretical support for a social movement with egalitarian tendencies."{{sfn|Guénon|2004|p=93}} According to Guénon, Sinnett, who "at the beginning probably contributed more than anybody else to make [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|Theosophism]] known in Europe, was genuinely fooled by all of Mme Blavatsky's tricks."{{sfn|Guénon|2004|p=36}} Some Theosophists did not share the views presented by Sinnett in his new work; for example, according to [[Anna Kingsford|Kingsford]], this book was very distant from the esoteric, and the main mistake of the author was that he thought about the symbols as reality.{{sfn|Washington|1995|loc=Ch. 4}} == New editions and translations == After its first publication in 1883 the book was reprinted several times: in the same 1883 came 2nd edition, in 1885 – 5th, 1898 – 8th. This work has been translated into several European languages: French, German, Italian, Spanish, Russian.{{sfn|Formats and editions}}{{refn|group=note|"153 editions published between 1883 and 2016 in 8 languages and held by 610 WorldCat member libraries worldwide".{{sfn|WorldCat Identities}}}} == See also == * [[Buddhism and Theosophy]] * ''[[Incidents in the Life of Madame Blavatsky]]'' * "[[Is Theosophy a Religion?]]" * ''[[Mahatma Letters]]'' * "[[The Esoteric Character of the Gospels]]" * ''[[The Occult World]]'' * ''[[The Secret Doctrine]]'' * [[Theosophy and Western philosophy]] == Notes == {{Reflist|group=note}} == References == {{Reflist|20em}} === Sources === * {{cite book |ref={{SfnRef|Glossary|1999}} |last=|first= |title=Encyclopedic Theosophical Glossary |location= |publisher=Theosophical University Press |date=1999|url=http://www.theosociety.org/pasadena/etgloss/etg-hp.htm |isbn=978-1-55700-141-2 |authorlink= |edition= |origyear= |series=|access-date =21 January 2017}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/esoteric-buddhism/oclc/894150821 |title=Esoteric Buddhism (eBook)|date= |publisher=[[OCLC]] [[WorldCat]] |access-date=21 January 2017 |ref={{SfnRef|WorldCat}}}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/esoteric-buddhism/oclc/682754/editions |title=Formats and editions of ''Esoteric Buddhism'' |date= |publisher=[[OCLC]] [[WorldCat]] |access-date=21 January 2017 |ref={{SfnRef|Formats and editions}}}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.worldcat.org/identities/lccn-n50026420/ |title=Sinnett A. '''Eutrapelia''' comes from the [[Greek language|Greek]] for '[[wittiness]]' (εὐτραπελία), referring to pleasantness in conversation. It is one of [[Aristotle|Aristotle's]] [[virtues]], the [[Golden mean (philosophy)|"golden mean"]] between boorishness (ἀγροικία) and buffoonery (βωμολοχία). Later on it came to mostly signify jokes that were obscene and coarse. The word appears only once in the [[New Testament]], in [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Ephesians%205:4 Ephesians 5:4], where it is translated "coarse jesting" in the [[NIV]].
==References== * {{cite web|url=http://fosterheologicalreflections.blogspot.com/2009/02/brief-word-study-on-eutrapelia.html|title=Foster's Theological Reflections: Brief Word Study on Eutrapelia|last=Foster|first=Edgar|accessdate=2009-06-02}} * Hoffmann, Tobias. “''Eutrapelia'': The Right Attitude toward Amusement.” In ''Mots médiévaux offerts à Ruedi Imbach'', edited by Iñigo Atucha, Dragos Calma, Catherine König-Pralong, and Irene Zavattero, 267–77. F.I.D.E.M. Textes et études du moyen âge. Porto: Fédération Internationale des Instituts d’Études Médiévales, 2011.

'''Exclusivism''' is the practice of being [[:wikt:exclusive|exclusive]]; [[mentality]] characterized by the disregard for opinions and ideas other than one's own, or the practice of organizing entities into groups by excluding those entities which possess certain traits. (for an opposite example, see [[essentialism]]).
==Religious exclusivism== {{Main|Chosen people|One true faith}} Religious exclusivism, one of the three classic typologies created by [[Alan Race]] in order to describe religions relative to one another, states that one religion, to the exclusion of all others, has the correct understanding of God, truth and salvation. [[Diana L. Eck|Diana Eck]] states, ‘Exclusivism is more than simply a conviction about the transformative power of the particular vision one has; it is a conviction about its finality and its absolute priority over competing views’.<ref>Pratt, Douglas. "Exclusivism and Exclusivity: A Contemporary Theological Challenge." ''Pacifica'' 20.3 (2007): 296.</ref> While it was originally used to define Christianity, exclusivism can apply to any religious belief system, as can Race’s other two categories [[inclusivism]] and [[Religious pluralism|pluralism]]. In his 1982 ''[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Christians-Religious-Pluralism-Christian-Religions/dp/0334019389/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1521581557&sr=8-2&keywords=alan+Race+religious+pluralism Christians and Religious Pluralism],'' Race defined pluralism as all religions being equally beneficial, with no single religion dominating. Inclusivism attempts to straddle the poles of pluralism and exclusivism by agreeing with the latter that one religion (Christianity) has the most value, and agreeing with the former by stating that other religions still have significant value.<ref>Tuggy, Dale. "Religious Diversity, Theories Of." ''Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy'', 2015.</ref> While Race’s three categories have been criticized, amended and refuted, most religious studies and interfaith scholars and students find the typologies useful as a starting point for conversations about the diversity of religions.<ref>D'Costa, Gavin. "The Impossibility of a Pluralist View of Religions." ''Religious Studies'' 32.2 (1996): 223-24</ref>
== Basic Three-point typology ==
=== Pluralism === Pluralism was borne out of a criticism of exclusivism, saying that no single tradition has a monopoly on revelation or salvation, and that we have no way to judge between the salvific claims by adherents of any faith tradition. [https://www.rsis.edu.sg/profile/paul-hedges/#.WrF9WMPFLDc Paul Hedges] suggests that each religion knows ‘transcendent reality (“God”) yet in partial perspective,’ much like the oft-quoted parable of the seven blind men and the elephant.<ref>Hedges, Paul. “A Reflection on Typologies: Negotiating a Fast-Moving Discussion.” ''Christian Approaches to Other Faiths''. Paul Hedges and Alan Race, eds. (London: SCM, 2008): 18.</ref> [[Gavin D'Costa|Gavin D’costa]] says pluralists have two main critiques of exclusivists: people of other religions are god and loving and that they do not know their own Scriptures well enough.<ref>D'Costa, Gavin. "The Impossibility of a Pluralist View of Religions." ''Religious Studies'' 32.2 (1996): 227.</ref> [[Alvin Plantinga]] says that pluralist’s problem with exclusivism stems from its immorality and arrogance. He quotes William Cantwell Smith: ‘Except at the cost of insensitivity or delinquency, it is morally not possible actually to go out into the world and say to devout, intelligent, fellow human beings: “…we believe that we know God and we are right; you believe that you know God, and you are totally wrong.”’<ref>Plantinga, Alan. “Pluralism: A Defense of Religious Exclusivism.” ''The Rationality of Belief and the Plurality of Faith'', Thomas D. Senor (ed). (Ithaca: Cornell University Press, 1995): 176.</ref> Along with Smith, the leading proponent of pluralism is John Hick, who writes:
[Exclusivism], with its baleful historical influence, in validating centuries of anti-semitism, the colonial exploitation by Christian Europe of what today we call the third world, and the subordination of women within a strongly patriarchal religious system, not only causes misgivings among many Christians but also alarms many of our non-Christian neighbors, creating invisible but powerful barriers within the human community.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Pluralism and Particularity in Religious Belief|last=Stetson|first=Brad|publisher=Praeger|year=1994|isbn=|location=Westport CT and London|pages=117}}</ref>
It is worth noting that D’costa argued persuasively that logically, pluralism can no longer be considered a category; when it makes a declarative truth claim, it becomes another form of exclusivism.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=D'Costa|first=Gavin|date=1996|title=The Impossibility of a Pluralist View of Religions 32.2 (1996): 223-32|url=|journal=Religious Studies|volume=32:2|pages=225|via=}}</ref>
=== Inclusivism === Inclusivists state that while one religion or revelation is true (Christianity), other truths can be found in fragments within other religions.<ref>D'Costa, Gavin. "The Impossibility of a Pluralist View of Religions." ''Religious Studies'' 32.2 (1996): 225.</ref> [[Karl Rahner]] states it succinctly: ‘Insofar as they in good conscience practice what is good in their religion, people in other religions receive God’s grace and are “anonymous Christians,” people who are being saved through Christ, though they do not realize it.’ <ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Tuggy|first=Dale|date=2015|title=Religious Diversity, Theories Of|url=|journal=Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> Inclusivists point to the biblical parable of the sheep and the goats in which the saved sheep show surprise at being rewarded for their service to [[Jesus]] (Matthew 25: 31-40)<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Moser|first=Paul|date=2010|title=Religious Exclusivism|url=|journal=The Oxford Handbook of Religious Diversity|volume=|pages=86|via=}}</ref>
=== Exclusivism in Christianity and other religions === According to Race, the history of the Abrahamic faiths’ exclusivism – as well as inclusivism – goes back to the words of the Bible and the Qur’an.<ref name=":1">Race, Alan. “Theologies of Religions in Change: Factors in the Shape of a Debate.” ''Christian Approaches to Other Faiths''. Paul Hedges and Alan Race, eds. (London: SCM, 2008): 14.</ref> Christian exclusivists point to John’s gospel (14: 6), which quotes Jesus as saying, ‘I am the way and the truth and the life. No one comes to the Father except through me.’ After Jesus’ death, his disciple Peter said publicly, ‘Salvation is found in no one else, for there is no other name under heaven given to mankind by which we must be saved’ (Acts 4:12). Likewise, the Qur’an (3:85) states, ‘If anyone desires a religion other than Islam (submission to Allah), never will it be accepted of him; and in the Hereafter He will be in the ranks of those who have lost (all spiritual good).’ While Judaism does not stress salvation, the First Commandment (Exodus 20:3) is ‘You shall have no other gods before me.’ Race says, ‘The tension between Christian experience and the recognition of potential authentic practice outside of the Christian revelation, in fact has always existed in Christian history from the beginning, from the words of Jesus himself in the gospel of Luke: in 9:50 he says, “He who is ''not against'' us is for us”’.<ref name=":1" /> Daniel Strange points out what Race neglects to mention: that in the same gospel (11:23), Jesus says, ‘He who is ''not with me'' is against me.’<ref>Strange, Daniel. “Exclusivisms: ‘Indeed Their Rock is Not like Our Rock.’ ''Christian Approaches to Other Faiths''. Paul Hedges and Alan Race, eds. (London: SCM, 2008) 37.</ref>
== No salvation outside the Church == The exclusivist idea of ‘no salvation outside of the Christian church’ (''[[Extra Ecclesiam nulla salus|Extra ecclesiam nulla salus]]'') has roots as early as [[Origen]] in the third century.<ref name=":0" /> And while the Bible speaks about many topics of inclusion, diversity and tolerance in both the Old and New Testament – attitudes toward the alien and stranger; the hope of Christians being drawn from all nations and languages; God’s universal care and sustaining of creation; the universal scope of the gospel and the universal mandate to take the gospel to the nations<ref>Strange, 38.</ref> – the overwhelming feeling in the Church throughout most of its history mimics that of the [[Council of Florence]] in 1422: ‘The Council firmly believes, professes and proclaims that those not living within the Catholic Church, not only pagans, but Jews, heretics and schismatics, cannot participate in eternal life, but will depart into everlasting fire which has been prepared for the devil and his [sic] angels.’<ref>Strange, 40.</ref> [[Martin Luther]] continued the exclusivist theological bent: ‘For where Christ is not preached, there is no Holy Spirit to create, call and gather the Christian Church, and outside it no one can come to the Lord Christ’.<ref>Strange, 41</ref> The door in the exclusivist castle opened a crack during the 20th century missionary movement, when Dutch missiologist [[Hendrik Kraemer]] wrote that Jesus is the one who has the complete authority to judge other religions’ efficacy.<ref>Strange, 43.</ref> Highlighting a unique contemporary take on the salvation problem, Strange introduces [[George Lindbeck]]’s contention that those who do not know the Bible cannot be condemned for their lack of knowledge.<ref>Strange, 44.</ref>
== New wave of exclusivism == Mara Brecht states that the problem with classic exclusivism is that it deals mainly with Christianity and salvation (or ‘top down’). She highlights the work of the ‘New Wave of exclusivism,’ led by Griffiths, D’costa and Netland, who employ a ‘bottom up’ approach to religious diversity.<ref>Brecht, Mara. "What's the use of Exclusivism?" ''Theological Studies'' 73.1 (2012): 34.</ref> New Wave Exclusivists focus more on the religious believers’ ‘ways of knowing and understanding of religious beliefs as expressive truth,’ resulting in a broader possibility for interfaith engagement.<ref>Brecht, 34.</ref> For example, Netland sets aside comparing religions’ salvation when he says dialogue should focus on the most important question all religions deal with – the question of truth.<ref>Brecht, 43.</ref> Brecht reaches the conclusion that exclusivism is tenable for Christians – and by extension other religious believers – if believers come into contact with believers of other religions who can possibly ‘defeat’ their own, so they can have something to base their truth claims on. Brecht says, ‘Practically, this means that, for example, reflective Christians will consider their beliefs to be as ''probable'' as alternatives from within their own tradition, ''somewhat more probable than'' the relevant alternatives from within Judaism and ''considerably more probable than'' Buddhist alternatives. In other words, believers will weigh their beliefs against other beliefs.’<ref>Brecht, 54.</ref>
== Divisions of exclusivism == Douglas Pratt further defines exclusivism, dividing it into three subdivisions – open, closed and extreme. Citing t’Hooft and Kraemer, Pratt says open exclusivism, while never ceding the superior position, ‘may at least be amenably disposed toward the other,’ if only in order to know Them well enough for possible conversion. The relationship is not entered into on equal ground, therefore, nor with the openness to a significant reciprocal change of self-identity. If dialogue is entered into, it is only for mutual edification and an increase in good will.<ref>Pratt, Douglas. "Exclusivism and Exclusivity: A Contemporary Theological Challenge." ''Pacifica'' 20.3 (2007): 297.</ref> Closed exclusivism offers no chance for a relationship, other than acknowledging the other’s right to exist. An extreme, hard-line exclusivism often leads to a fundamentalist perspective. Pratt writes, ‘Fundamentalism, as a mindset, is a mentality that expresses the modern quest for universality and coherence writ large: only one truth; one authority; one authentic narrative that accounts for all; one right way to be.’<ref>Pratt, 293.</ref> The logical conclusion for this fundamentalist mindset is taking steps to eliminate the other, as one would a business competitor. Pratt writes, ‘The negation of otherness is perhaps critical, for it involves a devaluing and dismissal of the "other," whether in terms of rival community or competing alterities, ideological or otherwise. In the process of negating the other, the self is asserted as inherently superior. My God is greater than your god.’<ref>Pratt, 298-99.</ref>
[[Paul Moser]] posits two forms of exclusivism: logical religious exclusivism, which asserts that since the contradictory, foundational truth claims for each religion excludes some or many of them from being true;<ref>Moser, Paul K. "Religious Exclusivism." ''The Oxford Handbook of Religious Diversity'' (2010): 78.</ref> and the doxastic redemptive exclusivism based on the Athanasian Creed, which states if a person does not believe the Christian concept of the Trinity, that person is condemned. Moser further believes that a God who would exclude people from salvation for neither hearing nor understanding the concept of the Trinity does not have a moral character, and is therefore undeserving of worship.<ref>Moser, 83.</ref>
== Exclusivism in other religions == While most attention of exclusivism points toward Christianity, each religion has a branch that falls into the exclusivist category. D’costa<ref>D'cost, 224.</ref> points out whether one considers oneself Buddhist or Hindu or Muslim – or indeed a pluralist – each version states that ‘only one single revelation or one single religion is true and all other “revelations” or religions are false.’ While acknowledging that historically, Christianity showed the most extreme forms of exclusivism, Pratt contends that many fundamentalist religions compete for that title, with Islam leading other worthy contenders<ref>Pratt, 298.</ref> in ways that are not always obvious. With the purging of the [[Rohingya people|Rohingya]] in [[Myanmar]], the Buddhist Rakhine have joined the ranks of fundamentalists willing to resort to killing to achieve dominance over competing religions.<ref>Lee, Morgan. “Love Thy Neighbor: South Asia Christians Advocate for Rohingya Muslims.” ''Christianity Today'', Oct. 27, 2017.</ref>
==In Ancient Greece== The Decree of Diopithes (430 BCE) forbade the worship of and belief in gods other than those of the Olympian pantheon recognised by the Athenian polis. The introduction of other gods was treated as ''asebeia'', or [[impiety]], and was punishable by death. The philosophers [[Anaxagoras]], [[Protagoras]], [[Socrates]], [[Stilpo]], [[Theodorus the Atheist|Theodorus of Cyrene]], [[Aristotle]], and [[Theophrastus]] were accused of impiety under this decree. Socrates was found guilty of the charge of introducing new gods and condemned to death by drinking [[conium|hemlock]].
[[Antiochus IV Epiphanes]], [[Selucid]] ruler of Israel, decided to Hellenize the Jews by ordering the worship of Zeus; when they refused, Antiochus sent an army to enforce his decree.
According to [[Herodotus]] the Caunians, a Greek people who claimed to have originated in Crete and settled in Asia Minor, worshiped the Olympian Gods exclusively. "They determined that they would no longer make use of the foreign temples which had been established among them, but would worship their own old ancestral Gods alone. Then their whole youth took arms, and striking the air with their spears, marched to the Calyndic frontier, declaring that they were driving out the foreign Gods."
[[Plato]], in his Laws, advocates that the state should punish those who deny the existence of the Olympian Gods or believe that the gods exist but think they are indifferent to mankind or can be easily bought by bribes.
''[[Interpretatio graeca]]'', the common tendency of ancient Greek writers to identify foreign divinities with members of their own pantheon, can be seen as a kind of exclusivism. The [[syncretism]] of the [[Hellenistic]] period whereby aspects of the cults of foreign Gods such as iconography and epithets, can also be seen as a kind of exclusivism.
=== Exclusivism and religious diversity in America === In a sociological survey of Americans and their relationship with religions other than Christianity, nearly 90 percent of respondents either strongly or somewhat agreed that “religious diversity has been good for America,” which reinforces the idea that Americans value diversity and religious freedom.<ref>Merino, Stephen. "Religious Diversity in a "Christian Nation": The Effects of Theological Exclusivity and Interreligious Contact on the Acceptance of Religious Diversity." ''Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion'' 49.2 (2010): 237.</ref> However, respondents who identified in the exclusivist category or believed that the United States was a Christian nation displayed much more negative views and a decreased willingness to include other religious people in the lives of their community.<ref>Merino, 243.</ref> Stephen Merino concludes, ‘It may be that when many Americans think of “religious diversity,” they have only Christian diversity in mind.’ <ref>Merino, 244.</ref> Nevertheless, they also provided research to back up their statement, ''‘''Prior contact with non-Christians will be associated with more positive views of religious diversity and increased willingness to include non-Christians into social life.’ <ref>Merino, 235.</ref>
=== Exclusivism and truth === In answering the pluralist charge, and hearkening back to Netland, Brad Stetson baldly states, ‘It is possible exclusivism is true.’ <ref>Stetson, 115.</ref> It is this statement, he says, that upsets pluralists who charge exclusivists with arrogance and bad form. ‘It is simply not true, as pluralists imply, that disagreeing with someone […] about religious truth is tantamount to treating them badly.[…] [a]n exclusivist claim about religious truth is not defeated strictly because such claims are believed to militate against human harmony and peace.' <ref>Stetson, 118.</ref> In addition, Hick, Smith and other pluralists balk at the idea that an all-loving God would condemn some people to hell,<ref>Stetson, 119.</ref> nor that anyone actually deserves to be damned;<ref name="Stetson, 123">Stetson, 123.</ref> he then quotes CS Lewis: ‘The doors of hell are locked on the ''inside.’'' <ref name="Stetson, 123"/>

In [[philosophy of language]], a context in which a sub-sentential expression ''e'' appears is called extensional if and only if ''e'' can be replaced by an expression with the same extension and necessarily preserve [[truth-value]]. The [[Extension (semantics)|extension]] of a term is the set of objects that that term denotes.
Take the case of [[Clark Kent]], who is secretly [[Superman]]. Suppose that [[Lois Lane]] fell out of a window and Superman caught her. Thus the statement, "Clark Kent caught Lois Lane," is true because it has an '''extensional context'''. The names "Superman" and "Clark Kent" have the same extension, which is to say that they both refer to the same person, i.e., that superhero who is vulnerable to [[kryptonite]]. Anybody that Superman caught, Clark Kent caught.
In opposition to extensional contexts are intensional contexts, where synonymous terms cannot be substituted in without potentially compromising the truth-value. Suppose that Lois Lane believes that Clark Kent will investigate a news story with her. The statement, "Lois Lane believes that Superman will investigate a news story with her," is false, even though Superman is Clark Kent. This is because 'believes' is typically an intensional context.

The '''Four Sages''', '''Assessors''',<ref name="Legge">[[James Legge|Legge, James]]. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=QUCZEPUyvBAC The Confucian Analects, the Great Learning, & the Doctrine of the Mean]''. 1893.</ref> or '''Correlates''' ({{zh|c={{linktext|四|配}}|p=Sì Pèi}}) are four eminent [[Chinese philosophy|Chinese philosopher]]s in the [[Confucianism|Confucian]] tradition. They are traditionally accounted a kind of sainthood and their [[spirit tablets]] are prominently placed in [[Confucian temple]]s, two upon the east and two upon the west side of the Hall of the Great Completion (''Dacheng Dian'').
The Four Sages are: * [[Yan Hui]], Confucius's favourite [[disciples of Confucius|disciple]] * [[Zengzi]] or Zeng Shen, another disciple of Confucius and author of the ''[[Great Learning]]'' * [[Zisi]] or Kong Ji, Confucius's grandson, student of Zengzi, and author of the ''[[Doctrine of the Mean]]'' * [[Mencius]] or Master Meng, student of Zisi and author of the ''[[Mencius (book)|Mencius]].''
Within a traditional Confucian temple, Yan Hui's tablet is placed first to the east of Confucius.<ref name="Legge"/>
The families of the descendants of the Four Sages [[w:zh:四氏|四氏]] still hold hereditary offices in the Republic of China (Taiwan) such as the [[Sacrificial Official to Confucius]], "Sacrificial Official to [[Mencius]]", "Sacrificial Official to [[Zengzi]]", and "Sacrificial Official to [[Yan Hui]]".<ref>http://news.xinhuanet.com/tw/2009-07/24/content_11764658.htm</ref><ref>http://news.sina.com.cn/o/2009-07-23/101716000328s.shtml</ref><ref>http://www1.rfi.fr/actucn/articles/115/article_15023.asp</ref><ref>http://blog.xuite.net/ahhsiang/TYDA/20446373-【文史雜記】大成至聖先師奉祀官</ref> They use [[Generation_name#Generation_poem|generation poems]] for their names given to them by the Ming and Qing Emperors.<ref>{{zh icon}} [http://www.ndcnc.gov.cn/datalib/2004/HundredName/DL/DL-20031203183333/ 孔姓 (The Kong family, descendents of Confucius)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903010033/http://www.ndcnc.gov.cn/datalib/2004/HundredName/DL/DL-20031203183333/ |date=September 3, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{zh icon}} [http://www.ndcnc.gov.cn/datalib/2004/HundredName/DL/DL-20040216142301 孟姓 (The Meng family, descendents of Mencius)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060116060231/http://www.ndcnc.gov.cn/datalib/2004/HundredName/DL/DL-20040216142301 |date=January 16, 2006 }}</ref>
<poem> :希言公彥承，宏聞貞尚衍； :興毓傳繼廣，昭憲慶繁祥； :令德維垂佑，欽紹念顯揚； :建道敦安定，懋修肇彝常； :裕文煥景瑞，永錫世緒昌。 </poem>

The '''Great Tew Circle''' was a group of clerics and literary figures who gathered in the 1630s at the [[manor house]] of [[Great Tew]], [[Oxfordshire]] in southern England, and in London.<ref name="Remer2008"/> [[Lord Clarendon]] referred to the Circle as "A college situate in a purer air", referring to its pursuit of truth away from the partisan passions of the town. The quote is referenced by [[John Buchan]] in his story "Fullcircle", though he misquotes it as "clearer air". The house was the property of the noble Cary family, and the circle was brought together by [[Lucius Cary, 2nd Viscount Falkland|Lucius Cary]], who became 2nd Viscount Falkland on the death of his father in 1633. The most prominent of those taking part was [[Edward Hyde, 1st Earl of Clarendon|Edward Hyde]], the future 1st Earl of Clarendon, who after 1660 would become known as a leading statesman, and then a historian.<ref>{{cite book|editor=Ted-Larry Pebworth|title=Literary circles and cultural communities in Renaissance England|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ih1sRzuOAhMC&pg=PA174|accessdate=24 March 2012|year=2000|publisher=University of Missouri Press|isbn=978-0-8262-1317-4|page=174}}</ref>
==Views== [[File:FalklandEngraving.jpg|thumb|Late engraving (1811) of Lord Falkland, after a portrait by [[Cornelis Janssens van Ceulen]]]] In the vexed religious climate of the time, the Circle was heterodox, inclining to sympathy with [[Socinianism]].<ref name="Mortimer2010">{{cite book|author=Sarah Mortimer|title=Reason and Religion in the English Revolution: The Challenge of Socinianism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fYeP_htzw14C&pg=PA63|accessdate=24 March 2012|date=4 March 2010|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-51704-1|pages=63–5}}</ref> The favoured approach of some of those involved has been defined as "[[Arminianism|Arminian humanism]]", and in any case opposed to rigid [[Calvinism]];<ref>See [[Arminianism in the Church of England]].</ref> this approach fitted with political views that were essentially [[royalist]].<ref name="Müller2009">{{cite book|author=Patrick Müller|title=Latitudinarianism and didacticism in eighteenth century literature: moral theology in Fielding, Sterne, and Goldsmith|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ArqOiaObh9UC&pg=PA17|accessdate=24 March 2012|date=19 January 2009|publisher=Peter Lang|isbn=978-3-631-59116-1|pages=17}}</ref> The central religious figure of the Circle was [[William Chillingworth]].<ref name="Sorell1996">{{cite book|author=Tom Sorell|title=The Cambridge Companion to Hobbes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iaHbJNClqjQC&pg=PA22|accessdate=24 March 2012|date=26 January 1996|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-42244-4|pages=22}}</ref> Falkland himself had a Catholic convert, [[Elizabeth Cary, Lady Falkland]], for his mother, and found the tolerant approach of [[Erasmus]] attractive.<ref name="Quantin2009">{{cite book|author=Jean-Louis Quantin|title=The Church of England and Christian antiquity: the construction of a confessional identity in the 17th century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QwNmY0UFfakC&pg=PA215|accessdate=24 March 2012|date=25 April 2009|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-955786-8|pages=215}}</ref>
==Influences== Major influences on the thinking of the circle were [[Hugo Grotius]]<ref name="Remer2008">{{cite book|author=Gary Remer|title=Humanism and the Rhetoric of Toleration|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SyXardgwY6EC&pg=PA144|accessdate=24 March 2012|date=31 January 2008|publisher=Penn State Press|isbn=978-0-271-02811-8|pages=144}}</ref> and [[Richard Hooker]] because of the place the latter made for the use of reason in Biblical interpretation and [[church polity]].<ref>Michael Brydon, ''The Evolving Reputation of Richard Hooker: An examination of responses 1600–1714'' (2006), p. 52.</ref> These writers formed part of the broader Christian humanist tradition of [[Jacobus Acontius]], [[George Cassander]], [[Sebastian Castellio]], [[Bernardino Ochino]] and [[Faustus Socinus]].<ref name="Remer2008"/> The anti-[[patristic]] views of [[Jean Daillé]] were also significant.<ref name="Packer1969">{{cite book|author=John William Packer|title=The transformation of Anglicanism, 1643-1660: with special reference to Henry Hammond|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jBwNAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA69|accessdate=24 March 2012|year=1969|publisher=Manchester University Press ND|pages=69|id=GGKEY:2UELGKR2ZUF}}</ref> According to the writings of Hyde (as Lord Clarendon), the gatherings and discussions themselves were modelled on those of Cicero and Erasmus, with guests being welcome to differ on points of view. Discourse also took place around the dinner table, with Clarendon likening the "''Convivium Philosophicum'' or ''Convivium Theologicum'' ("philosophical-" or "theological feast") to Erasmus's ''Convivium Religiosum'' ("godly feast")."<ref name="Remer2008"/>
==Tolerance, eirenicism, latitude== Chillingworth was influenced by Acontius, and the Circle read Acontius alongside [[Johannes Crellius]], a Socinian.<ref>{{cite book|author=John Marshall|title=John Locke, Toleration and Early Enlightenment Culture: Religious Intolerance and Arguments for Religious Toleration in Early Modern and 'Early Enlightenment' Europe|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dRb-P3HRuvkC&pg=PA324|accessdate=25 March 2012|date=30 March 2006|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-65114-1|pages=324}}</ref> They found greater relevance in the [[eirenicism]] of Acontius than in the theology ([[Unitarianism]]) of Socinus himself.<ref>{{cite book|author=Sarah Mortimer|title=Reason and Religion in the English Revolution: The Challenge of Socinianism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fYeP_htzw14C&pg=PA6|accessdate=25 March 2012|date=4 March 2010|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-51704-1|pages=6}}</ref> The context, as explained by the historian [[Hugh Trevor-Roper]], was that of the [[Thirty Years' War]] with its Protestant defeats of the 1620s and Catholic expansion; but also of the doctrines of the [[contra-Remonstrants]] in an environment of increasing [[skepticism]] on religious matters.<ref>{{cite book|author=Reid Barbour|title=Literature and Religious Culture in Seventeenth-Century England|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tKHhA2-u2pkC&pg=PR80|accessdate=25 March 2012|year=2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-00664-4|pages=lxxx}}</ref> Falkland and Chillingworth had been seared by the "[[Pyrrhonism|Pyrrhonian]] crisis" of skepticism rampant.<ref>Hugh Trevor-Roper, ''From Counter-Reformation to Glorious Revolution'' (1992), p. 176.</ref> Opposed to [[fideism]], the Circle found in the use by Grotius of [[probabilism]] a more attractive option to deal with the challenge of skepticism.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Daniel Garber|author2=Michael Ayers|title=The Cambridge History of Seventeenth-Century Philosophy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BPlkkgIhUXIC|pages=1034 and 399|accessdate=26 March 2012|year=2003|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-53720-9}}</ref>
Trevor-Roper supported the claims of the Great Tew group to the eirenic moral high ground on [[religious toleration]] and a commitment to rational dialogue on religion. This analysis has been challenged from the direction of the Circle's political thought, with its commitment to [[sovereignty]]. It has also been argued that these are two sides to the understanding of the period of the term "Socinian".<ref name="Mortimer2010"/> The eirenic style was understood by Puritan opponents as Arminian rhetoric, and they moved away from compromise with it, to polemic and contemplation of war.<ref name="Dodds2009">{{cite book|author=Gregory D. Dodds|title=Exploiting Erasmus: the Erasmian legacy and religious change in early modern England|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sE70JHsZVakC&pg=PA212|accessdate=25 March 2012|date=9 April 2009|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-0-8020-9900-6|pages=212}}</ref>
The major theologians of the circle (Chillingworth, Hales, Taylor) have regularly been claimed as precursors of the [[Latitudinarian]]s, a term anachronistic before 1660.<ref>E.g. [[Edward Augustus George]], ''Seventeenth Century Men of Latitude; forerunners of the new theology'' (1908); [https://archive.org/details/seventeenthcentu00georialaarchive.org].</ref> They are now considered to have paved the way for the [[Cambridge Platonists]], in the attitude that there is no single basis of essential and true beliefs.<ref name="Haakonssen2006">{{cite book|editor=Knud Haakonssen|title=Enlightenment and Religion: Rational Dissent in Eighteenth-Century Britain|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oOY56Aqh77YC&pg=PA20|accessdate=25 March 2012|date=2 November 2006|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-02987-2|pages=20}}</ref> The distinction now usual between the Cambridge Platonists and other Latitudinarians is a conventional one, introduced by [[John Tulloch]] in the 19th century.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Martin Ignatius Joseph Griffin|author2=[[Richard Henry Popkin]]|author3=Lila Freedman|title=Latitudinarianism in the seventeenth-century Church of England|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PXGPCglRAxYC&pg=PA12|accessdate=25 March 2012|year=1992|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-09653-0|page=12}}</ref>
==Participants== Participation in any actual dialogues as described by Hyde is problematic to establish; and the time scale has different points on it, though a beginning date of 1634 (Martinich) seems to be agreed widely. After about 1640 the troubled political situation overshadowed theoretical discussion and writing. The influence of the circle can be traced in theological production (especially Chillingworth's ''Religion of Protestants'', 1638),<ref>In full ''The Religion of Protestants, a safe way to salvation, or, An answer to a booke entitle Mercy and truth, or, Charity maintain'd by Catholiques, which pretends to prove the contrary'' (Oxford, 1638).</ref> literary works and translation in a humanist vein, and the political line pursued by Falkland and Hyde in 1640–1, attempting to find a middle position between Puritan and Laudian extremes. [[File:Falkland Memorial - geograph.org.uk - 1181172.jpg|thumb|Memorial to Falkland, who died at the [[first battle of Newbury]] of 1643, fighting recklessly on the royalist side, some 30 miles south of Great Tew]] Among those mentioned as being in Falkland's circle are:
;Churchmen *[[George Aglionby]]<ref>Malcolm, p.92 note 53.</ref> *[[Thomas Barlow (bishop)|Thomas Barlow]]<ref name=Cressy>{{ODNBweb|id=6676|title=Cressy, Hugh Paulinus|first=Patricia C.|last=Brückmann}}</ref> *William Chillingworth<ref name=Cressy/> *[[Hugh Paulinus Cressy]]<ref name=Cressy/> *[[John Earle (bishop)|John Earle]]<ref name=Cressy/> *[[Charles Gataker]]<ref name="Martinich, p. 103">Martinich, p. 103.</ref> *[[John Hales]]<ref name=Cressy/><ref name=Chill>{{ODNBweb|id=5308|title=Chillingworth, William|first=Warren|last=Chernaik}}</ref> *[[Henry Hammond]]<ref name=Cressy/> *[[George Morley]]<ref name=Cressy/><ref name=Chill/> *[[Walter Raleigh (priest)|Walter Raleigh]] the cleric.<ref>{{ODNBweb|id=23040|title=Raleigh, Walter|first=David|last=Underdown}}</ref> *[[Gilbert Sheldon]]<ref name=Cressy/><ref name=Chill/> *[[Jeremy Taylor]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Kim Ian Parker|author2=Canadian Corporation for Studies in Religion|title=The biblical politics of John Locke|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PRk2jfp_eoEC&pg=PA17|accessdate=25 March 2012|date=1 March 2004|publisher=Wilfrid Laurier Univ. Press|isbn=978-0-88920-450-8|pages=17}}</ref>
;Men of letters *[[Thomas Carew]]<ref name=PCary>{{ODNBweb|id=4842|title=Carew, Thomas|first=Nicholas|last=Jagger}}</ref> *Charles Cotton (died 1658), father of [[Charles Cotton]] the poet.<ref>{{cite book|author=Edward Hyde, Earl of Clarendon|title=The History of the Rebellion: A New Selection|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tg5Oi6qCy_gC&pg=PA489|accessdate=25 March 2012|date=12 February 2009|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-160777-6|pages=489}}</ref> *[[Abraham Cowley]]<ref name="Martinich, p. 103"/> *[[Sidney Godolphin (poet)|Sidney Godolphin]]<ref>{{ODNBweb|id=10881|title=Godolphin, Sidney|first=Anne|last=Duffin}}</ref> *[[George Sandys]]<ref>{{ODNBweb|id=24651|title=Sandys, George|first=James|last=Ellison}}</ref> *[[John Suckling (poet)|Sir John Suckling]]<ref name=PCary/> *[[Thomas Triplet]]<ref name="Martinich, p. 103"/> *[[Edmund Waller]]<ref name=Chill/>
;Politicians and lawyers *[[Dudley Digges]]<ref>Martinich, pp. 63–4.</ref> *Edward Hyde<ref name=Cressy/> *[[John Selden]]<ref>Martinich, pp. 63–4, and p. 217.</ref>
===Associations=== Since Great Tew was best known as an open house for Oxford scholars, and Falkland's contacts included a group centred on London and the court, it is artificial at best to assign membership in the circle to some who are known to have associated with the group.
*[[Thomas Hobbes]].<ref name=PCary/> Whether Hobbes actually visited Great Tew is unclear; he possibly did so in 1634. His associations with the circle through friendships are more certain in a London context.<ref>{{cite book|author=Tom Sorell|title=The Cambridge Companion to Hobbes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iaHbJNClqjQC&pg=PA23|accessdate=25 March 2012|date=26 January 1996|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-42244-4|pages=23}}</ref> *Poets: [[Ben Jonson]] was on good terms with members of the circle, and visited Great Tew;<ref>{{ODNBweb|id=15116|title=Jonson, Benjamin|first=Ian|last=Donaldson}}</ref><ref>Martinich, p. 217.</ref> [[Thomas May]] associated with the circle.<ref>{{ODNBweb|id=18423|title=May, Thomas|first=David|last=Norbrook}}</ref> *Wits: [[George Digby, 2nd Earl of Bristol|George Digby]] and [[John Vaughan (judge)|Sir John Vaughan]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Robert Wilcher|title=The discontented cavalier: the work of Sir John Suckling in its social, religious, political, and literary contexts|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1nhdngJkFr4C&pg=PA175|accessdate=24 March 2012|year=2007|publisher=Associated University Presse|isbn=978-0-87413-996-9|pages=175}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Gordon McMullan|author2=Jonathan Hope|title=The Politics of tragicomedy: Shakespeare and after|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z4UOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA40|accessdate=25 March 2012|year=1992|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-415-06403-3|pages=40}}</ref> *[[Katherine Jones, Viscountess Ranelagh]], who moved to England from Ireland after the 1641 rebellion.<ref>{{cite book|author=Sylvia Monica Brown|title=Women, gender, and radical religion in early modern Europe|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wIyI0T4DVVgC&pg=PA289|accessdate=25 March 2012|year=2007|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-16306-5|pages=289}}</ref> *Sons of [[Thomas Coventry, 1st Baron Coventry]].<ref>{{ODNBweb|id=22607|title=Potter, Christopher|first=A. J.|last=Hegarty}}</ref> *[[Francis Wenman]] and [[Henry Rainsford]], friends and neighbours of Falkland, linked to the [[Virginia Company of London]].<ref>Malcolm, pp. 74–5.</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Preston T. King|title=Thomas Hobbes: critical assessments|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Fp3UvaGcjuMC&pg=PA348|accessdate=25 March 2012|year=1993|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-415-08081-1|pages=348}}</ref> *[[Robert Payne (naturalist)|Robert Payne]] and [[Thomas Lockey]], on the Great Tew–Oxford axis of the 1630s.<ref>Malcolm, p. 325.</ref> *The Catholics [[Kenelm Digby]] and [[Wat Montagu]], possibly.<ref name="Martinich, p. 103"/> *[[Izaak Walton]], biographer of Hooker, not likely to have participated at Great Tew, but close to a number of the Circle.<ref name="Pebworth2000">{{cite book|author=Ted-Larry Pebworth|title=Literary circles and cultural communities in Renaissance England|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ih1sRzuOAhMC&pg=PA178|accessdate=25 March 2012|year=2000|publisher=University of Missouri Press|isbn=978-0-8262-1317-4|pages=178}}</ref>
==Relationship to other groups== Falkland himself is identified as one of the [[Tribe of Ben]], the followers of Jonson;<ref>{{cite book|author=Virginia Brackett|title=The Facts On File Companion to British Poetry|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3XTxs-X-gSwC&pg=PA452|accessdate=25 March 2012|year=2008|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-1-4381-0835-3|pages=452}}</ref> and others of the Circle were also in the Tribe. Falkland also gave the first of the poetical tributes in the 1638 Oxford memorial volume ''Jonson Virbius'', and others of the Circle who contributed were [[Henry Coventry]], May and Digges.<ref>[[Barrett Wendell]], ''The Temper of the Seventeenth Century in English Literature (1904), p. 136;[https://archive.org/stream/temperseventeen00wendgoog#page/n150/mode/2up archive.org].</ref>
Hales and Chillingworth have been identified with an "Oxford School of rational theology", containing also [[Christopher Potter]] and William Page.<ref>{{cite book|author=Nicholas Tyacke|title=Aspects of English Protestantism, c. 1530-1700|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=McvcmiZ6h8gC&pg=PA279|accessdate=25 March 2012|year=2001|publisher=Manchester University Press|isbn=978-0-7190-5392-4|pages=279}}</ref> It has been said that, despite the political difference over the defence of [[episcopacy]], there is no clear distinction between the Great Tew line and Laudianism in theology.<ref>{{cite book|author=Paul D. L. Avis|title=Anglicanism and the Christian Church: theological resources in historical perspective|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zUq-NYXtfUwC&pg=PA73|accessdate=25 March 2012|year=2002|publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-567-08745-4|pages=73}}</ref> Falkland, Hyde and [[Sir John Colepepper]] were leaders of the "Country Alliance" of 1640.<ref>[[J. S. Morrill]], ''The Revolt of the Provinces: Conservatives and Radicals in the English Civil War 1630–1650'' (1980), p. 19.</ref>
Katherine Jones was someone common to the Great Tew Circle and the [[Hartlib Circle]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Steven Shapin|title=A social history of truth: civility and science in seventeenth-century England|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K9eI7TGxLCsC&pg=PA144|accessdate=25 March 2012|year=1994|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0-226-75018-7|pages=144 note 49}}</ref> Robert Payne was a central figure in the so-called [[Welbeck Academy]], around the Cavendishes, with which Hobbes was more closely associated than with Great Tew.<ref>{{cite book|author=Juhana Lemetti|title=Historical Dictionary of Hobbes's Philosophy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6N_-lu-p7IoC&pg=PA352|accessdate=3 April 2012|date=16 December 2011|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-0-8108-5065-1|pages=352}}</ref> [[File:Letice Falkland.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Letice Cary, Viscountess Falkland, as a widow]] The widowed Lady Falkland (Letice or Lettice) took in [[John Duncon]], brother of [[Eleazar Duncon]] and [[Edmund Duncon]], who had lost his Essex rectory during the Civil war. He later wrote her biography (1648, in the form of an exchange of letters).<ref>{{cite DNB|wstitle=Duncon, Eleazar}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=John Duncon|author2=Lettice Cary (viscountess Falkland.)|title=The holy life and death of the lady Letice, vi-countess Falkland, with the returnes of spiritual comfort and grief in a devout soul. Repr. (of part of the 1648 ed.).|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FNACAAAAQAAJ|accessdate=29 March 2012|year=1760}}</ref> It has been suggested that the household was run on lines similar to that at [[Little Gidding]].<ref>A. L. Maycock, ''Nicholas Ferrar of Little Gidding'' (1938), note p. 231.</ref>
